args: Put this article into one of the following categories. Use the most specific category that makes sense. If you are unsure, respond Other. The allowed categories are: Abortion, AI, Associated Press, Birthright citizenship, CFPB, Climate, Crypto, D.C., Debt ceiling, DEI in schools, DEI in the federal government, Department of Education, Deportations, DOGE, End birthright citizenship, Eric Adams case, Expanding executive power, Federal funding, Federal grant pause, Federal office space, Federal worker buyout, Federal workers return to office, Federal workforce reductions, FEMA, Firing government watchdogs, Food safety, Foreign aid, Foreign policy, Gaza, Government shutdown, Guantánamo Bay, Health agencies' communications pause, Health care, Immigration policy, Interest rates, Iran, Islamic State, Israel, Jan. 6, Kennedy Center, NIH, NYC congestion toll, Other, Panama Canal, Pardons, Reclassifying federal jobs, Sanctions, Senior government officials ousted, Taiwan, Targeting political enemies, Targeting protesters, Tariffs, The media, TikTok ban, Transgender policy, U.S.-Mexico border, USAID, USPS, War in Ukraine, World Health Organization Respond ONLY with the category. Trump revokes security clearances for dozens of former national security officials Trump in an executive order on Monday directed the revocation of any active security clearances held by John Bolton, his former national security adviser, and the living signatories of a notorious October 2020 letter suggesting that emails purportedly taken from a laptop belonging to Hunter Biden could be part of a “Russian information operation.” The action all together targets 50 former national security officials, including several former directors of the Central Intelligence Agency. Some of the former officials no longer have security clearances, making the impact of the order unclear. A Bolton representative did not immediately respond to a request for comment. Bolton, a former ambassador to the United Nations, served as Trump’s national security adviser for 17 months, ending in September 2019. In 2020, he published a memoir about his time in the administration that included damaging assessments of the president, portraying him as reckless and unfit for office. In Monday’s order, Trump claimed that Bolton’s book was “rife with sensitive information drawn from his time in government,” an assertion that the former national security adviser has denied. The president has long assailed the signatories of the October 2020 letter, calling the statement a form of “election interference.”
